metadata.title: Submit a complaint for weeds that are causing damage or harm

email.responseTime: We aim to respond as soon as possible.

metadata.submissionGuidance:
If your complaint is valid, the Injurious Weeds Complaints team at Natural England will aim to acknowledge it within 10 working days.

Natural England will not act on complaints received between 1 October and 31 March. If you submit a complaint form during this period, it will not be acknowledged until after 1 April. 

If we consider the weeds to be high risk, we’ll contact the landowner or occupier to ask them to remove the weeds by a specific date. We’ll let you know about this action.

If we consider the weeds to be low risk, we’ll not usually act straight away but will ask you to:

* continue to monitor the spread of the weeds
* contact an adviser again within 12 months if you think the risk of weeds spreading is increasing

pages.title: How the weeds are spreading

components.name: FauLmU
components.content:
Use Defra Magic maps to help us understand how the weeds are spreading.

  1. Go to Defra Magic maps (opens in new tab).
  2. Search the location to bring up the area.
  3. Select 'Drawing Tools' in the toolbar at the top.
  4. Use the line tool to draw a line around the boundary of your land in blue and the land from which the weeds are spreading from in red.
  5. To download your map, select the 'Print' icon in the toolbar at the top.
  6. Enter a map title (your last name) in the text box.
  7. Select 'Format' then select 'JPG'.
  8. Select 'Print'.
  9. Select the 'Printout' link that appears below. This will bring up a new window.
  10. In the new window, right-click and then select 'Save image as', name your file with your last name then select 'Save'.

components.name: kQFTLP
components.title: Can you send us a Magic map?

pages.title: Details of who owns or occupies the land

components.name: Qiyxah
components.title: Html
components.content:
Natural England need to know who owns or occupies the land where the weeds are spreading from. If you do not provide the details of the landowner or occupier, Natural England will not be able to investigate your complaint.

Use the Search for land and property information service (opens in new tab) to find out who owns the land or property.

components.name: zkKRoO
components.hint: These include their name, address, contact number and email address.
components.title: Do you know contact details of the landowner or occupier?

If your land does not have an address, you must provide one of the following:

  • what3words location (opens in new tab)

  • RLR field parcel number

components.name: aBWflD

pages.title: Landowner or occupier contact details

components.name: TRjRkz
components.content:
You must provide an address for the landowner or occupier and either their:

  • phone number
  • email address

Providing an email address will reduce delays when communicating with the landowner or occupier.

Natural England will be unable to investigate your complaint if you do not provide a way to contact the landowner or occupier.

components.name: JshbLv
components.title: Email address of the landowner or occupier

components.name: OGUsuT
components.title: Phone number of the landowner or occupier

components.name: tcWmCo
components.title: Address of the landowner or occupier

pages.title: Are you the owner or occupier of land threatened by injurious weeds?

components.name: vKISeM
components.title: Owner or occupier of land threatened by injurious weeds

pages.title: You're not eligible to submit a complaint

components.name: cZGbak
components.title: Html
components.content: To submit a complaint, you must be the owner or occupier of the land threatened by injurious weeds. Natural England do not investigate the spread of injurious weeds onto the land of a third party.

pages.title: You're not eligible to submit a complaint

components.name: BuWiQG
components.title: Html
components.content:
To submit a complaint, the land must be:

  • used for keeping or grazing horses or other livestock
  • farmland used to produce conserved forage
  • used for other agricultural activities

Natural England will not investigate complaints for land used for other purposes.

pages.title: You're not eligible to submit a complaint

components.name: SQRQZj
components.title: Html
components.content: To submit a complaint, you must know the contact details of the landowner or occupier.

pages.title: Why have you not attempted to contact the landowner or occupier?

components.name: BLEyWn
components.title: Reason for not contacting land owner
components.hint: You should have attempted to resolve the matter with the landowner or occupier before submitting a complaint.

pages.title: What's the name of the landowner or occupier?

components.name: OMpCSp
components.title: Name of land owner

pages.title: Map outlining the land where the weeds are spreading from

components.name: TXTuJo
components.title: Html
components.content:
If you cannot create a map with Magic Maps, an alternative map of any kind will help Natural England identity the affected areas.

Mark the alternative map to show:

  • the land infested with injurious weeds in one colour
  • your land at risk (within 100 metres) in a different colour

When you've submitted your complaint, email your map to weedenquiries@naturalengland.org.uk

You must include your name in the email subject and the date you submitted your complaint.

pages.title: What did the landowner or occupier say when you contacted them?

components.name: jlZjRY
components.title: Landowner response
components.hint: Provide contact dates and a summary of any action taken.

pages.title: Upload a map

components.name: dLzALM
components.title: Documents

pages.title: How the weeds are spreading

components.name: FauLmU
components.content:
Use Defra Magic maps to help us understand how the weeds are spreading.

  1. Go to Defra Magic maps (opens in new tab).
  2. Search the location to bring up the area.
  3. Select 'Drawing Tools' in the toolbar at the top.
  4. Use the line tool to draw an arrow or arrows to show how the weeds are spreading.
  5. To download your map, select the 'Print' icon in the toolbar at the top.
  6. Enter a map title in the text box.
  7. Select 'Format' then select 'JPG'.
  8. Select 'Print'.
  9. Select the 'Printout' link that appears below. This will bring up a new window.
  10. In the new window, right-click and then select 'Save image as', name your file then select 'Save'.

Email your saved image to weedenquiries@naturalengland.org.uk.
